metadata.title: CT scans and 3D models of reindeer metatarsals from modern Finnish populations
metadata.description:
This dataset contains raw CT scans and derived 3D models of 117 modern reindeer metatarsals from Finland, including both subspecies present in the region: semi-domesticated mountain reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) and wild forest reindeer (Rangifer tarandus fennicus). Specimens exhibit a range of lifestyles: free-ranging (wild or semi-domesticated), racing (semi-domesticated trained for racing), zoo (captive), and draught (semi-domesticated used for sled pulling).

All specimens originate from the osteological collections of the Biodiversity Unit, University of Oulu (Oulu, Finland), and were collected within the framework of the Domestication in Action project. For each individual, one metatarsal — either right or left — was scanned individually using a clinical CT scanner and subsequently reconstructed into a 3D model.

The Excel file included in the dataset provides detailed specimen information, including ID, subspecies, laterality, sex, castration status, age, lifestyle, and location.

This dataset provides high-resolution morphological data suitable for studies on reindeer osteology, functional anatomy, and comparative analyses, including research on domestication processes.

These data have been previously used in Pelletier et al. (2022) – Impact of selection and domestication on hindlimb bones of modern reindeer populations: Archaeological implications for early reindeer management by Sámi in Fennoscandia. Historical Biology 34(5):802-820.

data.title: CT scans and 3D models of reindeer metatarsals from modern Finnish populations

The Excel file included in the dataset provides detailed specimen information, including ID, subspecies, laterality, sex, castration status, age, lifestyle, and location.

metadata.title: XRF-Scan, grain-size, and XRD Data from the southeast Pacific sediment core MR16-09 PC3
metadata.description: These 2 data files contain the XRF-scanned Ti and Br counts data, grain-size (medium-to-coarse silt fraction; GS-EM4 component) and XRD-based amphibole contents data from core MR16-09 PC3, covering the last glacial period (10–80 ka).

metadata.title: Evaluation of any relationship between serum calcium and uric acid levels with Computed Tomography (CT scan) Stone Densit
metadata.description:
Both of Calcium & uric acid are important in stone formation, There are multiple risk factors for stone formation such as: low fluid intake,hypercalciuria,primary hyperparathyroidism, high salt diet, high animal protein intake. Computed tomography CT is currently used most commonly to predict the type and opacity of stone (stone density) measured in HU. (Hounsfield unit)

 A total of 100 adult patients with renal stone, discovered by abdominal ultrasound examination, were chosen, there was no significant difference in the mean stone density in terms of patients’ age, gender, and BMI, the patients with high uric acid levels had significantly higher mean stone density when compared to the patients with low or normal levels of uric acid, Patients with high serum calcium levels may have high CT stone density.

metadata.title: Pulmo Scan: A Deep Learning Framework for Pneumonia Detection using X-Ray Images
metadata.description: Pneumonia is an acute respiratory infection of the lung that must be identified at its early stages to keep mortality rates to a minimum, especially in Wireless Body Area Networks (WBAN). Traditional diagnosing methods, i.e., manual interpretation of X-rays, are time-consuming and prone to human errors. The existing models are plagued by generalizability issues, dataset imbalance, and a high false-detection rate, which complicate pneumonia classification. To address these challenges, we propose a CNN-based model that leverages transfer learning to improve detection accuracy. The model consists of three convolutional layers, dropout regularisation, the Adam optimiser, and robust data augmentation methods to learn improved features and prevent overfitting. We trained the model on the Chest X-ray dataset (NORMAL vs. PNEUMONIA) containing 5,863 images. We achieved enhanced accuracy across five state-of-the-art models in our experiments, with higher precision, recall, and F1 Scores. Additionally, the model generalises well by leveraging diverse preprocessing techniques, including image resizing, normalisation, and various forms of augmentation. Compared with existing architectures such as VGG-16, ResNet50, and InceptionV3, the model demonstrated improved robustness and classification accuracy. This research facilitates the development of a solid deep learning framework for detecting pneumonia to be incorporated into real-time medical software.

metadata.title: A Study towards Supervised Learning Techniques for a Well-Predictive Modelling Utilising Electronic Health Record Data
metadata.description: Electronic health records (EHRs) provide a substantial repository of structured and unstructured data, enabling predictive modelling for medical research and clinical decision-making. The gathered EHR data is more useful for machine learning; all the information about a diagnosed patient — such as their lab results, demographics, treatments, etc. — needs to be compiled, cleaned, and converted to a standard format for use. To start supervised learning, split the dataset into two sets: a training set and a test set. Then a model that works well is chosen, such as decision trees, logistic regression, random forests, or neural networks. People use these models to learn about diseases, the risks they pose, and the best treatments. To assess how well something works, model evaluation uses metrics such as precision and accuracy. We can learn more about patient care, achieve better results, and make medical associations more evidence-based by systematically applying supervised learning techniques to EHR data.

metadata.title: Complete symmetry-range scan at masses 10, 50, 100, 150, 200 GeV — multi-channel MET cross-checks and rebinning
metadata.description:
Short abstract:

Comprehensive symmetry-range scans were performed at target masses 10, 50, 100, 150 and 200 GeV across four principal final-state families (electron, muon, photon, jet) and their pairwise combinations. The analysis tests symmetry conservation in two groups — Strong Hypercharge (baryon number, strangeness, charmness, bottomness, topness) and Weak Hypercharge (energy, momentum, angular momentum, electric charge, lepton number, B−L, parity asymmetry, charge asymmetry, CP asymmetry, CPT asymmetry) — and compares group-level and global deltas at each mass point. Multiple MET regimes are examined using CaloMET and PFMET, plus crossed CaloMET–PFMET diagnostics to reveal reconstruction anomalies across trajectory and temperature-like regimes. The dataset includes flexible rebinning scripts (0.5 GeV → 0.005 GeV) to adapt resolution for follow-up studies.

Expanded description:

This dataset and supporting code provide a complete, reproducible symmetry-check workflow over a mass landscape sampled at 10, 50, 100, 150 and 200 GeV with the following features:

  • Mass scanning and binning

    • Primary scans across 0–200 GeV with configurable bin widths from 0.5 GeV down to 0.005 GeV via an included rebinning utility.

    • Predefined bin-centers and automated rebinner to produce high-resolution and coarse-resolution views.

  • Symmetry groups and tests

    • Strong Hypercharge group: baryon number (B), strangeness (S), charmness (C), bottomness (b), topness (t).

    • Weak Hypercharge group: energy (E), linear momentum (p), angular momentum (J), electric charge (Q), lepton number (L), B−L, parity asymmetry, charge asymmetry, CP asymmetry, CPT asymmetry.

    • Each test computes per-bin counts, normalized rates, local significances, and group-level aggregations.

  • Comparative and delta diagnostics

    • Channel-level and group-level comparisons at each target mass (10, 50, 100, 150, 200 GeV).

    • Delta metrics quantifying differences between Strong and Weak groups and a global symmetry delta across masses.

    • Automated look-elsewhere correction hooks and configurable significance calculators.

  • Channels and MET diagnostics

    • Main channels: electron, muon, photon, jet plus pairwise and mixed combinations (e.g., eμ, μγ, γj, ej).

    • MET analysis: CaloMET, PFMET and crossed diagnostics (CaloMET/PFMET ratio, difference, anomaly flags).

    • Trajectory and temperature-like regime tests: segmentation of events by kinematic regimes, comparison of MET reconstruction stability across regimes.

  • Outputs and reproducibility

    • Histograms, peak lists, symmetry-violation arrays, per-event extraction utilities, and PDF/PNG figures.

    • Scripts to extract event lists for highest-significance bins (for duplication, weight, and trigger checks).

    • Example notebooks and minimal diagnostic jobs to reproduce focused checks for single files.

  • Creator entry (Name / Affiliation / ORCID):

    • Tomaz Dionísio, André Luís — École Pratique des Hautes Études Commerciales; Federal Center for Technological Education Celso Suckow da Fonseca; Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro — ORCID:0009-0006-4648-3804

  • Contact person:

    • André Luís Tomaz Dionísio — andreluisdionisio@gmail.com — Affiliation: École Pratique des Hautes Études Commerciales

  • Rights holder:

    • Rights holder: André Luís Tomaz Dionísio

metadata.title: CT scans and 3D models of reindeer metacarpals from modern Finnish populations
metadata.description:
This dataset contains raw CT scans and derived 3D models of 117 modern reindeer metacarpals from Finland, including both subspecies present in the region: semi-domesticated mountain reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) and wild forest reindeer (Rangifer tarandus fennicus). Specimens exhibit a range of lifestyles: free-ranging (wild or semi-domesticated), racing (semi-domesticated trained for racing), zoo (captive), and draught (semi-domesticated used for sled pulling).

All specimens originate from the osteological collections of the Biodiversity Unit, University of Oulu (Oulu, Finland), and were collected within the framework of the Domestication in Action project. For each individual, one metacarpal — either right or left — was scanned individually using a clinical CT scanner and subsequently reconstructed into a 3D model.

The Excel file included in the dataset provides detailed specimen information, including ID, subspecies, laterality, sex, castration status, age, lifestyle, and location.

This dataset provides high-resolution morphological data suitable for studies on reindeer osteology, functional anatomy, and comparative analyses, including research on domestication processes.

These data have been previously used in Pelletier et al. (2020) – Identifying early stages of reindeer domestication in the archaeological record: a 3D morphological investigation on forelimb bones of modern populations from Fennoscandia. Archaeological and Anthropological Sciences 12:169.

data.title: CT scans and 3D models of reindeer metacarpals from modern Finnish populations

metadata.title: CT scans and 3D models of reindeer radioulnae from modern Finnish populations
metadata.description:
This dataset contains raw CT scans and derived 3D models of 94 modern reindeer radioulnae from Finland, including both subspecies present in the region: semi-domesticated mountain reindeer (Rangifer tarandus tarandus) and wild forest reindeer (Rangifer tarandus fennicus). Specimens exhibit a range of lifestyles: free-ranging (wild or semi-domesticated), racing (semi-domesticated trained for racing), zoo (captive), and draught (semi-domesticated used for sled pulling).

All specimens originate from the osteological collections of the Biodiversity Unit, University of Oulu (Oulu, Finland), and were collected within the framework of the Domestication in Action project. For each individual, one radioulna — either right or left — was scanned individually using a clinical CT scanner and subsequently reconstructed into a 3D model.

The Excel file included in the dataset provides detailed specimen information, including ID, subspecies, laterality, sex, castration status, age, lifestyle, and location.

This dataset provides high-resolution morphological data suitable for studies on reindeer osteology, functional anatomy, and comparative analyses, including research on domestication processes.

These data have been previously used in Pelletier et al. (2020) – Identifying early stages of reindeer domestication in the archaeological record: a 3D morphological investigation on forelimb bones of modern populations from Fennoscandia. Archaeological and Anthropological Sciences 12:169.

data.title: CT scans and 3D models of reindeer radioulnae from modern Finnish populations
